body: Oh and another thing: where the fuck is everyone else finding out how to do superscript for ruqqus's markdown which doesn't support it?!!!! I *still* don't know how even though I'm trying to find out because there's no information about it anywhere. But everyone else just magically knows somehow! It's not that this is a particularly huge deal in itself, but when literally *every. single. thing.* in my life happens that way, it's a major thorn in the flesh. This is merely another example of how everyone knows and can find out and learn so much more than me with no effort, as I explained in the previous comment. This is how everything happens in my life.

It's not that this is a particularly huge deal in itself, but when literally every. single. thing. in my life happens that way, it's a major thorn in the flesh. This is merely another example of how everyone knows and can find out and learn so much more than me with no effort, as I explained in the previous comment. This is how everything happens in my life.

parent.body:
>So am I but I never find out about these things.

What have you been trying? With "these types of things", I mostly find them by chance or by reading others' posts and comments in meta subreddits.

>But when it comes down to it I don't even come close to a single person with a shared interest.

You have friends with shared interests like foxes and programming, right? Lately, you've been asking others about a lot of things. Were any of their responses helpful to you?

>I never have and can't learn or accomplish hardly anything, my mind is pretty much locked the way it is and can't change or learn or adapt.

I think it may be self-defeating to have this mindset. Maybe try focusing on a few interests that you like the most and try not to give up along the way. If something seems hard or you don't know which direction to go in, try asking others.

***

Sorry, I often have a hard time trying coming up with advice, and I'm not sure what to do when you feel like you can't develop a skill (I feel that too sometimes, but it's mostly because of laziness).
parent.body_html:
So am I but I never find out about these things.

What have you been trying? With "these types of things", I mostly find them by chance or by reading others' posts and comments in meta subreddits.

But when it comes down to it I don't even come close to a single person with a shared interest.

You have friends with shared interests like foxes and programming, right? Lately, you've been asking others about a lot of things. Were any of their responses helpful to you?

I never have and can't learn or accomplish hardly anything, my mind is pretty much locked the way it is and can't change or learn or adapt.

I think it may be self-defeating to have this mindset. Maybe try focusing on a few interests that you like the most and try not to give up along the way. If something seems hard or you don't know which direction to go in, try asking others.

Sorry, I often have a hard time trying coming up with advice, and I'm not sure what to do when you feel like you can't develop a skill (I feel that too sometimes, but it's mostly because of laziness).

body:
> What have you been trying? With "these types of things", I mostly find them by chance or by reading others' posts and comments in meta subreddits.

Trying to look them up (which never works for me for the same reason I can't find things to post) and experimenting different things myself. If it really is all just chance, chance certainly doesn't seem to like me at all.

> You have friends with shared interests like foxes and programming, right? Lately, you've been asking others about a lot of things. Were any of their responses helpful to you?

Unfortunately not really. I learned a few very specific things from them, but as for how to learn and discover on my own like they do, which is 95% of it, they either couldn't explain or in the case of some of them, didn't want to tell. More than anything it showed just how much more everyone else knows than me. So many things everyone talks about casually, even in the subjects I'm most interested in, are gibberish to me, and I don't know about 99% of the things that "everyone just knows". Not only that, but when they don't know something they can easily find the information or are clever enough to produce a solution to it at light speed (compared to me).

> Maybe try focusing on a few interests that you like the most and try not to give up along the way. If something seems hard or you don't know which direction to go in, try asking others.

I'm already doing that. It's just that I'm a destined failure and that doesn't work. I feel so alone because I don't know a single other person who has this problem. And the few rare times I do meet someone, they always suddenly overcome it for no apparent reason soon after I meet them. I'm the only one stuck with it forever and ever.
body_html:
What have you been trying? With "these types of things", I mostly find them by chance or by reading others' posts and comments in meta subreddits.

Trying to look them up (which never works for me for the same reason I can't find things to post) and experimenting different things myself. If it really is all just chance, chance certainly doesn't seem to like me at all.

You have friends with shared interests like foxes and programming, right? Lately, you've been asking others about a lot of things. Were any of their responses helpful to you?

Unfortunately not really. I learned a few very specific things from them, but as for how to learn and discover on my own like they do, which is 95% of it, they either couldn't explain or in the case of some of them, didn't want to tell. More than anything it showed just how much more everyone else knows than me. So many things everyone talks about casually, even in the subjects I'm most interested in, are gibberish to me, and I don't know about 99% of the things that "everyone just knows". Not only that, but when they don't know something they can easily find the information or are clever enough to produce a solution to it at light speed (compared to me).

Maybe try focusing on a few interests that you like the most and try not to give up along the way. If something seems hard or you don't know which direction to go in, try asking others.

I'm already doing that. It's just that I'm a destined failure and that doesn't work. I feel so alone because I don't know a single other person who has this problem. And the few rare times I do meet someone, they always suddenly overcome it for no apparent reason soon after I meet them. I'm the only one stuck with it forever and ever.

parent.body:
I can't tell you how to remove the watermark since I don't know how to do it myself, but I don't think that others are intentionally refusing to tell you things. I'm sure they'll do it if you ask. If they still don't tell you, it's probably because they don't know how to answer your questions (like me, for example), not because they actually want to "keep you down" and exclude you.

<sup> - sfrohne [If you're going to post a screenshot of this comment, **don't** censor my username]</sup>

body: It's obvious that they did, and that they are also changing mail-in votes. Trump had more votes this year than he did last year. Yet Biden, who hardly anyone I know voted for, rapidly took the lead in every critical state after they "counted more votes". And in one case in PA a population got ZERO Trump votes. ZERO. *Or* maybe they were tampering and changed the votes to Biden or didn't count the Trump ones. You choose what to believe, but the latter is much more likely. On top of that, there was some issues with voting machines and giving people the wrong instructions to vote in some places, which would cause their votes to not count, mysteriously all in red areas.
body_html: It's obvious that they did, and that they are also changing mail-in votes. Trump had more votes this year than he did last year. Yet Biden, who hardly anyone I know voted for, rapidly took the lead in every critical state after they "counted more votes". And in one case in PA a population got ZERO Trump votes. ZERO. Or maybe they were tampering and changed the votes to Biden or didn't count the Trump ones. You choose what to believe, but the latter is much more likely. On top of that, there was some issues with voting machines and giving people the wrong instructions to vote in some places, which would cause their votes to not count, mysteriously all in red areas.

guild.description:
This guild is about News far and wide!

Sister guild: +Commentary

#1. Things that are posted to News should be stated like a fact in the Headline.

In the sense, Headline: X happened or X said this. Not Personal opinions. 

They should be reporting.

#2. Personal slant or commentary should go in the comments, not the Headline. Commentary content (like discussion commentator shows) are not News. Commentary content will be redirected to +Commentary which is for that purpose. 

If it's News but is more an opinion piece please add [Opinion] in the title, or post in a topic specific guild. 

#3. No screenshots; provide a link, provide a source.

See Posting Etiquette pin for further explanation.
guild.description_html:
This guild is about News far and wide!

Sister guild: +Commentary

#1. Things that are posted to News should be stated like a fact in the Headline.

In the sense, Headline: X happened or X said this. Not Personal opinions.

They should be reporting.

#2. Personal slant or commentary should go in the comments, not the Headline. Commentary content (like discussion commentator shows) are not News. Commentary content will be redirected to +Commentary which is for that purpose.

If it's News but is more an opinion piece please add [Opinion] in the title, or post in a topic specific guild.

#3. No screenshots; provide a link, provide a source.

See Posting Etiquette pin for further explanation.
guild.name: News

parent.body:
Misleading title.  The article says that 21,000 dead people are on the voter rolls ... not HOW they voted.  It also stated that there was evidence of "voting after death" of 216, not 21,000.  

Definitely evidence of poor management and controls in PA, though, and some direct evidence of fraud.
parent.body_html:
Misleading title. The article says that 21,000 dead people are on the voter rolls ... not HOW they voted. It also stated that there was evidence of "voting after death" of 216, not 21,000.

Definitely evidence of poor management and controls in PA, though, and some direct evidence of fraud.

parent.body:
>But people shouldn't just be letting twitter and the rest of big tech get away with this crap.

This is the problem.  I want virtually no government regulation, but part of letting the market solve problems is that we need people willing to "vote with their wallet" so to speak.  How many conservatives do you see complaining about twitter or Facebook *on twitter or Facebook*?  There are alternatives.  They're not *currently* at a Twitter or Facebook level, but they can get there if people abandon the bullshit.

Hell, make it public.  Celebrities/politicians can publicly announce that they're moving off these platforms and why.  I reckon part of why people don't believe the censorship stories is the people complaining about it stick around.
parent.body_html:
But people shouldn't just be letting twitter and the rest of big tech get away with this crap.

This is the problem. I want virtually no government regulation, but part of letting the market solve problems is that we need people willing to "vote with their wallet" so to speak. How many conservatives do you see complaining about twitter or Facebook on twitter or Facebook? There are alternatives. They're not currently at a Twitter or Facebook level, but they can get there if people abandon the bullshit.

Hell, make it public. Celebrities/politicians can publicly announce that they're moving off these platforms and why. I reckon part of why people don't believe the censorship stories is the people complaining about it stick around.

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
> It's clear that you have terrible self esteem

Of course I do. What would you expect from someone who has half succeeded at maybe 1 or 2 things ever in their life, even just hobbies, while having to watch all their friends and the whole rest of the world just casually accomplish so much? I know you're not supposed to judge yourself that way and all that, and I don't. But it's still infuriating and depressing.

> constantly comparing yourself to those who are better only to demoralize yourself

No, I'm just looking at the people I happen to know and every single one of them blows me away with ease in every aspect, because I'm not good enough at anything to even accomplish anything worthwhile. I usually hope they can tell me how they don't fail 100000% of the time, but they either don't know or don't want to tell. Everyone else just has it all together and figured out and I'm a mess who doesn't know anything.

> Also your posts are awesome and discussion is almost always appreciated.

Maybe, but it's nothing more than a handful of shit reposts and camping on specific sources all the time. Everyone else can find tons of great new stuff in an hour. As for discussion, I never have ideas for new threads and I'm always the last to know (as with everything) about the ones made by other people, at which point everyone else has already commented and it's too late for me to participate in it. This never fails.

> If you really do wanna compare though, I'd say that you're doing better than most when it comes to contributing to this site.

Yeah, because most people aren't really that interested. I can usually be better than people who've never done something before, sure. But when it comes to being good enough to actually *accomplish* anything...nope, not a chance.
body_html:
It's clear that you have terrible self esteem

Of course I do. What would you expect from someone who has half succeeded at maybe 1 or 2 things ever in their life, even just hobbies, while having to watch all their friends and the whole rest of the world just casually accomplish so much? I know you're not supposed to judge yourself that way and all that, and I don't. But it's still infuriating and depressing.

constantly comparing yourself to those who are better only to demoralize yourself

No, I'm just looking at the people I happen to know and every single one of them blows me away with ease in every aspect, because I'm not good enough at anything to even accomplish anything worthwhile. I usually hope they can tell me how they don't fail 100000% of the time, but they either don't know or don't want to tell. Everyone else just has it all together and figured out and I'm a mess who doesn't know anything.

Also your posts are awesome and discussion is almost always appreciated.

Maybe, but it's nothing more than a handful of shit reposts and camping on specific sources all the time. Everyone else can find tons of great new stuff in an hour. As for discussion, I never have ideas for new threads and I'm always the last to know (as with everything) about the ones made by other people, at which point everyone else has already commented and it's too late for me to participate in it. This never fails.

If you really do wanna compare though, I'd say that you're doing better than most when it comes to contributing to this site.

Yeah, because most people aren't really that interested. I can usually be better than people who've never done something before, sure. But when it comes to being good enough to actually accomplish anything...nope, not a chance.

parent.body:
The internet can be a shitty place for self esteem because it makes it SO easy to compare yourself to other people. Before it existed, you could compare yourself you your friends, family, and to an extent a few people in your larger community. But now, its the entire WORLD. Wanna play guitar? In 1.252 seconds you can stream a video of the best guitarist who ever lived. Demotivating.

Having self esteem is not really compatible with comparing yourself to other people _period_, let alone the entire planet has to offer. So sorry you're feeling disheartened, ma dude. The only thing I would say is try to compare yourself to other people less? I know it's cliche but the only thing you can compare yourself to is how you were yesterday.
parent.body_html:
The internet can be a shitty place for self esteem because it makes it SO easy to compare yourself to other people. Before it existed, you could compare yourself you your friends, family, and to an extent a few people in your larger community. But now, its the entire WORLD. Wanna play guitar? In 1.252 seconds you can stream a video of the best guitarist who ever lived. Demotivating.

Having self esteem is not really compatible with comparing yourself to other people period, let alone the entire planet has to offer. So sorry you're feeling disheartened, ma dude. The only thing I would say is try to compare yourself to other people less? I know it's cliche but the only thing you can compare yourself to is how you were yesterday.

For what its worth, the names I recognize are typically from the comments, not the posters. And the same for myself, I like to believe adding to the discussion of the comments is enough of a contribution for myself.

I look at Ruqqus as a discussion board first and foremost. Discussions typically don't go far, but hey, that's alright, they rarely do anymore outside of private discussions and niche specialized communities.

post.title: HOW TO IMPROVE RUQQUS. EACH USER MUST TRY TO POST ONE GOOD THREAD A DAY. LETS GO NO MORE LURKING

author.bio:

author.bio_html:

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
Yeah, I can post the Babylon Bee articles before someone else does and that's *it*. Everyone else can magically find everything from all over the internet, not just specific places. Heck I created +foxes and rarely do I find something interesting that I hasn't been reposted 32109850983 times for 50 years. Yet everyone else in that guild finds stuff all the time with no effort, both from random dark corners of the internet that I everyone but me apparently knows about, and specific sources which I didn't know a single one of but *everyone* else does.

I'm also not good at making discussion or meta or idea threads, and with regards to participating in existing ones I'm always the last person to find it and by that point it's too late to say anything. Every. single. time.

It's like this is all some telepathic thing that most people share and I'm not a part of. This is *not* the only subject where this happens to me either, in fact I can't think of any parts of my life where this isn't the case, and no one else has this problem. A few times I've met someone who did, but they always soon overcome it and don't want to tell me how or why. I'm completely alone in this.

And on top of that I can't learn skills either, so if I'm interested in something I'll initially improve but then flatline and never become good enough to accomplish anything. *And* I'm not clever and can't think outside the box at *all*, so I often miss the solutions to even the simplest of problems.
body_html:
Yeah, I can post the Babylon Bee articles before someone else does and that's it. Everyone else can magically find everything from all over the internet, not just specific places. Heck I created +foxes and rarely do I find something interesting that I hasn't been reposted 32109850983 times for 50 years. Yet everyone else in that guild finds stuff all the time with no effort, both from random dark corners of the internet that I everyone but me apparently knows about, and specific sources which I didn't know a single one of but everyone else does.

I'm also not good at making discussion or meta or idea threads, and with regards to participating in existing ones I'm always the last person to find it and by that point it's too late to say anything. Every. single. time.

It's like this is all some telepathic thing that most people share and I'm not a part of. This is not the only subject where this happens to me either, in fact I can't think of any parts of my life where this isn't the case, and no one else has this problem. A few times I've met someone who did, but they always soon overcome it and don't want to tell me how or why. I'm completely alone in this.

And on top of that I can't learn skills either, so if I'm interested in something I'll initially improve but then flatline and never become good enough to accomplish anything. And I'm not clever and can't think outside the box at all, so I often miss the solutions to even the simplest of problems.

parent.body: Confused. In my country postal/absentee ballots are disproportionately used by the elderly and rural voters so there's normally a swing to the conservatives when those come in. I don't understand why in America 90% of those votes are on the left.
